title: Erdős Problem #635: Non-Divisibility Condition on Differences
description: For A ⊆ {1,...,N} with b-a ≥ t implying (b-a) ∤ b, is |A| ≤ (1/2 + o_t(1))N? For t=1, maximum is ⌊(N+1)/2⌋. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #635 originates from a letter to Ruzsa around 1980. It asks about the maximum size of subsets of {1,...,N} satisfying a non-divisibility condition on differences. For t=1, the answer is ⌊(N+1)/2⌋ (odd numbers). For t=2, Erdős showed one can exceed N/2 by c·log(N). References: [Gu83], [Ru99].
overview.problemStatement: For t ≥ 1 and A ⊆ {1,...,N}, suppose that whenever a, b ∈ A with b - a ≥ t, we have (b-a) ∤ b. How large can |A| be? Is |A| ≤ (1/2 + o_t(1))N? OPEN.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines IsNonDivisible, IsAdmissible, and the extremal function f(N,t). The t=1 case (odd numbers) and t=2 construction are axiomatized. The main conjecture is formalized as density approaching 1/2.
keyInsights: The condition b-a ≥ t and (b-a) ∤ b restricts which pairs can coexist in A
For t=1, odd numbers are optimal: any difference from an odd number has an even factor
For t=2, Erdős beats N/2 by c·log(N) using odd numbers plus certain powers of 2
The conjecture says the density is always close to 1/2 regardless of t
Connected to divisibility restrictions in combinatorial number theory

sections.title: Part I: The Non-Divisibility Condition
sections.summary: Defines IsNonDivisible and IsAdmissible for A ⊆ {1,...,N} with parameter t.

sections.title: Part II: The Extremal Function
sections.summary: Defines f(N,t) = sSup of admissible set sizes.

sections.title: Part III: The Case t = 1
sections.summary: Defines oddSet. Axioms: oddSet_admissible, oddSet_card, f_t1 = (N+1)/2.

sections.title: Part V: The Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Defines ErdosConjecture635: density ≤ 1/2 + ε for all t, large N. Axiom erdos_635.

sections.title: Part VI: Upper Bound
sections.summary: Axioms: f_upper_trivial (f ≤ N), f_t1_density (density → 1/2 for t=1).

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #635 asks whether the extremal density for the non-divisibility condition is always close to 1/2. The t=1 case is solved (odd numbers), but the general conjecture remains open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would clarify the structure of sets avoiding divisibility relations, connecting to extremal combinatorics and additive number theory.
openQuestions: Is the density always at most 1/2 + o_t(1)?
What is the exact behavior for small t ≥ 2?
Can the Erdős construction for t=2 be improved?
How does the extremal function depend on t?
